title: Beware the Gifts of Dragons: How D&D’s Open Gaming License May Have Become a Trap for Creators

last_post.content:
Very interesting essay about D&D and the argument about the OGL (Open Gaming Licence). Received wisdom is that the OGL was a great way to encourage third parties (small companies, freelancers etc) to make D&D-compatible material such as adventures or sourcebooks - and that the apparently-imminent cancelation of the OGL is a distaster, screwing over the indies.
But this essay argues that indy creation was always possible (and preferable) without the OGL.
Fascinating.
https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2023/01/beware-gifts-dragons-how-dds-open-gaming-license-may-have-become-trap-creators

title: Towards functional spin-echo BOLD line-scanning in humans at 7T - Magnetic Resonance Materials in Physics, Biology and Medicine

last_post.content:
Null-findings are important, but more difficult to prove and publish. Here is a null-finding #NewPaper / #NeuroNewPaper.

Line-scanning functional #MRI has both high spatial and high temporal resolutions, about 200 micrometers and 200 milliseconds. This is achieved by sacrificing spatial coverage, akin to a virtual BOLD electrode through the brain. Previously, we implemented a human line-scanning sequence using gradient-echo #BOLD #fMRI at 7T.

Spin-echo MRI sequences offer several advantages over gradient-echo MRI sequences, for example much improved spatial line-selection and microvascular specificity. However, despite many efforts, especially from the lead-author Luisa Raimondo, spin-echo line-scanning currently lacks adequate sensitivity for #neuroscience applications.

https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10334-022-01059-7

With the assistance of the curator of the Labadie collection, the most extensive archive of anarchist material in North America, we were able to track down a copy of this early CrimethInc. poster and add it to our archive.

https://crimethinc.com/posters/the-revolution-will-not-be-on-television-nothing-will-be-on-television

This design dates from a quarter of a century ago. It's the sort of hastily conceived poster that young punks who lived at densely-populated collective houses would compose and print at Kinko's at three in the morning in those days.

A dramatically improved version of the text of the poster later appeared in the inside cover of our book, Expect Resistance:

title: A Tool For Debugging Quantum Circuits

last_post.content:
Debugging a circuit of a #quantumcomputer is not as easy as for classical computers. Setting breakpoints, stopping the execution, peeking variables or the state and continuing is simply not possible.

"developing a quantum debugger is challenging due to the nature of a quantum computer; sneaking a peek at the value of a quantum state will cause either partial or complete collapse of the superposition and may destroy the necessary entanglement."

https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.01899

"measuring how cells in face-selective regions of the macaque visual cortex were affected by the manipulation of a movie’s temporal structure."

"During the first 200 ms of activity following the onset of the stimulus, the neural response profile to the content extracted from the movie had virtually no correspondence to the same neurons’ responses to the same content appearing in the movie itself"

The final total of donations to the #MicroMirror project for 2022 was $1256!

I spent about $4000 on the project out of pocket to get it started with some inertia, but these donations seriously help offset the cost of this project and keep it growing beyond how much I'm personally willing to spend on hardware.

Thanks to all of your support, we have 19 new #Linux download mirrors hosted in the US, Canada, Australia, and Colombia. These are turn-key appliances where we build the server and then ship them out to the network hosts, and then fully manage and monitor them remotely so the hosting network doesn't need to dedicate any engineering resources while still being able to support free software.

Across the fleet, we serve approximately 40TB of downloads per DAY, being primarily Ubuntu CD images, Fedora updates, Centos, and EPEL.

So, folks may see I've got a link to PEACE Canada in my bio.

I'm so happy to be able to say that under our PEACE Humane program, we've officially launched an app called Chick It Out to the Apple and Google Play app stores!

https://peacehumane.org/chick-it-out-app/
https://apps.apple.com/app/chick-it-out/id1630884075
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.peacehumane.chickitout&hl=en&gl=US

It's an AR app, aimed at elementary school age and up, that takes you through the development of a chick from embryo to hatching, as an alternative to school chick hatching programs. It also shows the different life stages of chickens, from chick to pullet to hen for females, and chick to cockerel to rooster for males, as well as an interactive view of different systems in a hen's anatomy (e.g. muscular, skeletal, digestive amd respiratory systems).

So, why create a #humane #vegan alternative to school #ChickHatching programs?

Every spring, we get flooded with calls from elementary school teachers, often somewhat panicked, trying to figure out what to do with the cute little fluffy chicks that they have by now gotten somewhat attached to. Unfortunately, the outlook for these chicks is not so great. Female chicks may be raised as layers, ultimately destined for slaughter when they are "spent". Male chicks don't have that option, and may more quickly be slaughtered for meat. Often, though, even that may not be an option as biosecurity controls might prevent chicks that were outside of a controlled environment from entering the food system, so those chicks are literally waste product to be disposed of. Teachers are sometimes directed to "deal with it themselves".

While farm animal sanctuaries are sometimes able to give some of these chicks homes, there is only ever so much space, and the flood of new hatched chicks from these programs every year is simply beyond their capacity to take in.

Chick It Out has been in development for some time, and we're happy to finally have it available for people to explore!

title: NASA’s Webb Confirms Its First Exoplanet

last_post.content:
So what have I been up to? Confirming the existence of a planet that is 99% the size of Earth and searching for its atmosphere!

This planet is about 300 degrees Celsius and tidally locked to it star (one side in perpetual daylight), so not exactly habitable for life as we know it 🥵

We don't clearly detect an atmosphere (expected, we don't have all our data yet!) but we also can't rule an atmosphere out at this point! 🪐🔭

https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2023/nasa-s-webb-confirms-its-first-exoplanet

title: Residents in Chicago, Illinois are Reclaiming Vacant Properties

last_post.content:
"For over a year now, [people in Chicago] have been reclaiming vacant properties owned by the Chicago Housing Authority. The city and its private contractors abandoned thousands of units of so-called public housing. They let the pipes burst and the walls mold over, just so they can call them uninhabitable, schedule them for demolition, and sell the lots to the highest bidder.

NO MORE. We are inhabiting the uninhabitable. We have dumpstered our homes.

The houses, many of which were sitting empty for years, have become FREE SPACES that hold so much more than a roof over our heads. They are home to anarchist libraries, food distros, parties, film screenings, dinners, constantly re-arranging affinities, intimacies, and an endless tide of batshit ideas and inciteful possibilities."

#Chicago #Illinois #Housing #HousingCrisis

https://itsgoingdown.org/residents-in-chicago-illinois-are-reclaiming-vacant-properties/

So, you want to style all siblings sitting between a `.upper` and `.lower` element in CSS?

That’s possible … thanks to the almighty `:has()` selector!

```css
.upper ~ :has(~ .lower) {
outline: 1px solid red;
}
```

Details on my blog: https://brm.us/css-sibling-scope
